channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Israel Strikes Near the Heart of Beirut
item.description: The attack on a health authority building killed at least nine, the Lebanese authorities said. The Israeli military said it had struck about 200 sites in Lebanon overnight.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Mandatory Credit: Photo by WAEL HAMZEH/EPA-EFE/Shutterstock (14754817g) Smoke rises from damaged buildings following Israeli airstrikes in Dahieh, a southern suburb controlled by Hezbollah in Beirut, Lebanon, 03 October 2024. The Lebanese National News Agency (NNA) said that Israeli airstrikes were carried out overnight in the southern suburb, along with shelling from warships at sea. Israel carries out airstrike on Dahieh, Beirut, Lebanon - 03 Oct 2024

item.title: After Successes, Israel’s Military Is in a ‘Long Game’ With No Clear Outcome
item.description: A year after perhaps the worst military and intelligence debacle in the country’s history, its armed forces have regained the momentum. Some ask: to what end?
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles at a staging area near the border with Lebanon on Sunday.

item.title: Amid Sanctions, Russian Oil Tankers Are Flying New Flags
item.description: A shadowy network of ships has registered in Gabon, highlighting how Vladimir V. Putin is building an economy beyond the reach of Western sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz and Jacob Judah
item.media:description: Dozens of tankers have registered in Gabon over the past year, records show, making that country’s ship registry one of the fastest-growing in the world.

item.title: S. Iswaran, Ex-Singapore Minister, Sentenced to 1 Year in Prison
item.description: The sentence for S. Iswaran, the former transportation minister who pleaded guilty last week, was longer than what prosecutors had sought.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: S. Iswaran, the former transportation minister of Singapore, had pleaded guilty to charges of accepting gifts that included tickets to the play “Hamilton.”

item.title: After Iran’s Missile Attack, Israel May Be Ready to Risk All-Out War
item.description: Israel seems ready to respond in a much more forceful and public way with Iran after Tehran launched its second massive missile attack on Israel this year, analysts and officials say.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building in Hod Hasharon, Israel, that was destroyed during Iran’s missile attack on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel’s Strikes in Beirut Brings the Once-Bustling Suburbs to a Standstill
item.description: Airstrikes targeting members of Hezbollah have brought the Dahiya neighborhoods south of Beirut to a standstill, its residents fleeing and businesses shuttering.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed street in Dahiya, the predominantly Shia southern suburbs of Beirut, after a barrage of Israeli airstrikes, on Wednesday.

item.title: White South African Farmer Accused of Feeding 2 Slain Black Women to Pigs
item.description: The grisly allegations have sparked debate over some of the country’s most explosive issues, including race, gender-based violence and farm ownership.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: People outside court in Polokwane, South Africa, on Tuesday, where three men have been accused of killing two women who went to a farm looking for food.

item.title: Mexican Military Fatally Shoots Six Migrants
item.description: The country’s defense ministry said the military officers who opened fire might have mistaken the migrants for cartel members.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and James Wagner
item.media:description: Members of the police and Mexican Army patrolling in the Tila community in Chiapas, Mexico, in June.

item.title: UK’s Conservatives Are Surprisingly Upbeat at Their Party Conference
item.description: At its annual convention in Birmingham, the party is energized by a leadership contest and seems largely undisturbed by broader questions over its electability.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Banners promoting the four leadership candidates at the Conservative Party’s annual conference in Birmingham, where the mood was cheerful. “I was expecting something a little more gloomy, seeing as we had been defeated,” one party member said. “It’s really positive, it’s buzzing.”

item.title: Putin Tries to Recruit More Soldiers, Encourage Bigger Families
item.description: President Vladimir Putin is throwing ever more resources at two interlocked priorities: recruiting more soldiers and encouraging bigger families.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A military recruiting poster in Kursk, Russia, in August. President Vladimir V. Putin has ordered the ranks of Russia’s army to increase by 180,000 service members to 1.5 million.

item.title: A Survivor of Clerical Sex Abuse Tells His Story at the Vatican
item.description: As a child, Laurence Gien was abused by a priest in South Africa. Decades later, he became the first survivor to recount his pain at the Basilica in front of Pope Francis and dozens of cardinals and bishops.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Laurence Gien on Tuesday at St. Peter’s Basilica, where he recounted having been abused as a child by a priest in South Africa. He told his story with Pope Francis in attendance.

item.title: 60 Dead After Boat Capsizes in Nigeria
item.description: The boat was carrying about 300 people on the Niger River. Rescuers continued to search for survivors.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Auwal and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The Niger River near Onitsha, Nigeria, in 2023. This year, the Niger River has seen the worst flooding since 2020.

item.title: Dozens of Migrants Die Off Djibouti After Smugglers Force Them to Swim
item.description: Many others are missing after Yemeni operators instructed hundreds of African migrants on two boats near the Djibouti coast to get off and swim, the International Organization for Migration said.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Migrants boarding a boat in Djibouti in 2019. The route between Africa and the Arabian Peninsula is perilous for such journeys.

item.title: Missing Out on Coldplay’s India Tickets, Some Fans Vented — Even to Police
item.description: When 13 million people tried to buy tickets for the band’s Mumbai shows, the ticketing site crashed. Many who came up short cried foul, both online and to the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Chris Martin of Coldplay performing in Las Vegas last month.

item.title: U.K. to Return Chagos Islands to Mauritius, Ending Colonial-Era Dispute
item.description: After years of legal wrangling and negotiations, Britain said it would surrender sovereignty of the archipelago in the Indian Ocean.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Diego Garcia, the largest island in the Chagos Archipelago, is the site of a major military base.

item.title: Abuse Claims Add to Telegram C.E.O. Pavel Durov’s Legal Troubles
item.description: The mother of three children with Pavel Durov has poked holes in the Russian tech titan’s carefully managed image through a criminal complaint and her account of their opulent lifestyle.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Clara Watt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irina Bolgar said she had a romantic relationship with the Telegram founder Pavel Durov for about a decade.

item.title: World Braces for Bigger Trade Wars if Trump Wins
item.description: Business owners and foreign governments are preparing for high tariffs and trade disruptions, depending on the outcome of the election.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sonat Birnecker Hart, owner of the Koval Distillery in Chicago. The prospect of renewed trade wars make it hard for businesses like hers to plan for the future.

item.title: A Climate Fund Could Pay Billions to Protect Trees in Amazon and Beyond
item.description: Brazil is proposing a fund that would pay countries to protect tropical forests that are crucial to curbing climate change. It would generate returns, too.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Garo Batmanian, the director of the Brazilian Forest Service and one of the architects of the Tropical Forests Forever Facility, in the forest bureau in Brasilia.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Strikes Leave 6 Dead in Beirut
item.description: Plus, new evidence in the Trump election case.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in Dahiya, a densely populated area south of Beirut.

item.title: Typhoon Krathon Makes Landfall in Taiwan, Bringing Drenching Rains
item.description: Two people have been killed and more than 10,000 evacuated, the authorities said. The downpour has triggered landslides and flooding.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and John Liu

item.title: ‘There’s No Safety’: Decision to Leave Ends in Tragedy for Lebanese Family
item.description: Zahraa Badreddine fled Nabatieh in southern Lebanon as Israeli airstrikes intensified, hoping to find safety in a predominantly Christian area closer to the coast. But last Sunday, an airstrike near Sidon killed her two children.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cassel, Meg Felling and Arijeta Lajka
item.media:credit: Matthew Cassel for The New York Times

item.title: Gilead Agrees to Allow Generic Version of Groundbreaking H.I.V. Shot in Poor Countries
item.description: Many middle-income countries are left out of the deal, widening a gulf in access to critical medicines.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A vial of lenacapavir, an injectable H.I.V. prevention drug. A generic version will be sold in 120 countries, but a few large countries, which together account for 20 percent of new infections, will not have access to a low-cost version.

item.title: Israeli Strikes on Gaza Schools and an Orphanage Kill Scores of Palestinians
item.description: The Palestinian Authority’s official news agency said the Israeli military operation had included an incursion by ground troops and airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Rescuers from Palestinian Civil Defense extracting a body from a collapsed building in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Says at Least 8 Soldiers Are Killed in Clashes With Hezbollah in Lebanon
item.description: The cross-border fighting appeared to be the first direct ground confrontation between the two sides since Israel invaded Lebanon this week.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Farnaz Fassihi, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank in a staging area near the Israeli-Lebanon border on Tuesday.

item.title: In Israel, Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, Is More Bitter Than Sweet
item.description: On Rosh Hashana, many Israelis longed for a return to normalcy after a year of escalating wars for the country.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Family and friends of an Israeli soldier who was killed in Lebanon, at his funeral on Wednesday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Israeli Troops Clashed with Hezbollah
item.description: Plus, what we learned from fashion month.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Maroun El Ras in southern Lebanon yesterday.

item.title: Israel-Hezbollah War: What to Know
item.description: An Israeli ground operation targeting Hezbollah forces in Lebanon recalls previous wars and raises fears of worse to come.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles in a staging area near the border with Lebanon on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Says He Won’t Support an Israeli Strike on Iran’s Nuclear Sites
item.description: His comments reflected a renewed effort by his administration to seek restraint from Israel to try to avoid a growing war in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Wednesday

item.title: Iran’s Strikes on Israel Appear Aimed at Shoring Up Regional Alliance
item.description: Iran’s second missile barrage against Israel is unlikely to deter its foe, experts say, but may help retain the support of the “Axis of Resistance” it has built up over years.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The majority of more than 180 ballistic missiles launched from Iran were shot down by Israeli air defenses with the help of the U.S. military.

item.title: Israel Confirms 1st Military Fatality in Lebanon Invasion
item.description: The military identified the soldier as Capt. Eitan Itzhak Oster, 22, from central Israel, but did not specify where he was killed.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: An Israeli helicopter releasing flares near the Israel-Lebanon border, as seen from northern Israel, on Wednesday.

item.title: Tesla Sales Increase, Suggesting Electric Car Demand Is Rebounding
item.description: The automaker reported a gain of 6.4 percent for the latest quarter, its first such increase this year.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: Tesla increased sales in part by offering car loans with relatively low interest rates.

item.title: Israel Bars UN Chief António Guterres From Entering the Country
item.description: Foreign Minister Israel Katz said the U.N. secretary general had not condemned Iran’s missile attack on Israel in strong enough terms. For his part, Mr. Guterres said he condemned the attack.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, at the U.N. in New York last month.

item.title: Ukraine Withdraws From Vuhledar, Town Long Under Russian Attack
item.description: Vuhledar had been under assault for almost three years. Russian forces entered it after a furious battle, and Ukraine ordered troops to retreat.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Explosions caused by Russian strikes on Ukrainian positions were seen in the distance along the road toward Vuhledar, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Why the Conflict Between Iran and Israel Has Raised Oil Prices Only Modestly
item.description: The fighting is increasing fears about oil supplies, but those worries are offset by greater global production and slowing demand in China.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed

item.title: US, France and Britain Say They Helped Israel During Iran Attack
item.description: Israel has said that Iran fired more than 180 missiles in the barrage on Tuesday, but that most were intercepted.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Israel’s missile defense system intercepted rockets after Iran fired a salvo of missiles on Tuesday.

item.title: Three Men Arrested After Explosions Near Israeli Embassy in Denmark
item.description: The arrests were made after two explosions, possibly from hand grenades, were reported near the embassy early on Wednesday morning, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Emil Helms/Ritzau Scanpix Denmark, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Israeli Embassy in Copenhagen on Wednesday.

item.title: Attitudes About Nasrallah Appear More Positive in Middle East Since His Death
item.description: Sentiment about the Hezbollah leader shifted after the Israeli strike that killed him, partly reflecting anger toward Israel, according to an analysis.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah, who led Hezbollah for 32 years, was a towering figure across the Middle East.

item.title: Israel’s Lebanon Invasion Leaves Christian Village Uprooted
item.description: Hundreds of residents of tiny Ain Ebel in southern Lebanon heeded the Israeli military’s warning to flee. Many sought shelter in a nearby monastery.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles in a staging area near the border with Lebanon on Tuesday.

item.title: Where U.S. Forces Are Deployed in the Middle East
item.description: The Pentagon is preparing to send more troops and aircraft to the region. This is an overview of the U.S. military presence there.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Agnes Chang
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Taiwan Closes Schools and Workplaces as Typhoon Krathon Nears
item.description: The storm has already injured 46 people and forced thousands of evacuations, the authorities said, warning that torrential rain could cause landslides and flooding.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and John Liu
item.media:description: Waves crashing onto the coastline in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Wider War in the Middle East, From Hamas to Hezbollah and Now Iran
item.description: The main questions now are how much the conflict will escalate and whether the United States will get more directly involved in the defense of Israel.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Israel’s Iron Dome missile defense system intercepted rockets after Iran fired a salvo of ballistic missiles on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Iran Fires 180 Missiles at Israel
item.description: Plus: In a lawsuit, words matter.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Israel’s air defense system intercepted many of the Iranian missiles, the military said.

item.title: Catholics Meet to Chart Church’s Future, but Not Women Deacons
item.description: The ordination of female deacons is no longer on the agenda during a global assembly at the Vatican, but will be discussed separately.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis during a meeting with bishops, priests, deacons and other pastoral workers in Brussels on Saturday.

item.title: Laborer From Gaza Is First Reported Fatality of Iran’s Missile Attack
item.description: Sameh al-Asali, who was sheltering in the city of Jericho in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, was killed when a large missile fragment slammed into him.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: People gathered around a fallen projectile that had been moved to the center of a square in the village of Dura in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday, after Iran launched a missile barrage at Israel.

item.title: Iran Launches 180 Missiles at Israel After Hezbollah and Hamas Assassinations
item.description: The 180 missiles fired at Israel on Tuesday evening sharply escalated the conflict between the two countries and threatened to engulf the Middle East in all-out war.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Eric Schmitt and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Projectiles being intercepted above Ashkelon, Israel, on Tuesday. Israel’s air defenses appeared to limit substantial damage from the missile attack, and minutes after it began, the Israeli military said, it appeared to have ended.

item.title: Song Binbin, Poster Woman for Mao’s Bloody Upheaval, Dies at 77
item.description: She was said to have been involved in the first killing of an educator during the Cultural Revolution, drawing official praise. She later apologized for her actions.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: As a student leader of the militant Red Guards, Song Binbin was selected to pin an armband around the sleeve of Mao Zedong in a ceremony in 1966 in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

item.title: Israel Weighs Retaliation After Iranian Missile Attack
item.description: Security analysts and former officials said the damage Israel had inflicted on Hezbollah, an Iranian-backed militia, had stripped Tehran of much of its deterrence against a wider Israeli attack.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli tanks near the border with Lebanon on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Says U.S. Warships Helped Israel Intercept Iran’s Missiles
item.description: The president said the United States was “fully, fully, fully supportive of Israel,” in a show of solidarity between two allies whose relations have become strained.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, told reporters at the White House on Tuesday that there had been “meticulous joint planning” between U.S. and Israeli forces to counter the Iranian missile attacks.

item.title: Videos Show Iranian Missile Attack on Israel
item.description: While some missiles were intercepted by Israeli air defense, several hit locations in Israel, according to an analysis by The Times.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis, Aric Toler, Devon Lum and Ainara Tiefenthäler

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Iran Launched Ballistic Missiles at Israel
item.description: Plus, Jimmy Carter turned 100.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: People took cover yesterday as a siren warned of incoming missiles near Kfar Saba, Israel.

item.title: Why Did Iran Strike Israel?
item.description: The barrage of missile fire came after much debate among Iranian leaders, officials there say.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians in Tehran cheering the strike on Israel.

item.title: What Are Ballistic Missiles?
item.description: A look at the kind of weapons fired into Israel.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: An Iranian ballistic missile was carried past a portrait of Gen. Qassim Soleimani, the leader of Iran’s Quds force, during a military parade last week.

item.title: France’s Prime Minister Urges a Divided Parliament to Give Him a Chance
item.description: Michel Barnier vowed to slash spending and temporarily raise some taxes, but his plan must contend with three bitterly opposed political blocs and an aversion in France to working across party lines.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier delivered his general policy speech to lawmakers in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel Has Destroyed Half of Hezbollah’s Arsenal, U.S. and Israeli Officials Say
item.description: The Lebanese militia is seeking more weapons from Iran, the officials said. It has yet to fire large barrages at Israel, and its top ranks have been crippled by Israeli strikes.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s recent airstrikes in Lebanon dealt a blow to Hezbollah, but the group’s arsenal is still formidable.

item.title: As Iran Launches a Missile Attack, Israel’s Next Move May Determine Course of War
item.description: A look back to an exchange of strikes in April suggests one possibility for what could unfold over the coming days.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eve Sampson
item.media:description: In April, the United States, Israel, Jordan and others intercepted almost all of the hundreds of missiles and drones in a barrage that Iran fired toward Israel. Israel responded without escalating the conflict.

item.title: Tel Aviv Shooting Leaves Six Dead and Several Injured
item.description: The authorities described the shooting, which took place on a light rail train, as a terrorist attack by two Palestinian gunmen. No group immediately claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Israeli police officers keep watch near a cordon at the site of a shooting incident in Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: Is That a Panda at the Zoo? Or a Dog in a Disguise?
item.description: Zoos around the world have occasionally used a little dye, or just brazenness, to pass off one animal as another.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: Maps: Where Israel Has Invaded Lebanon
item.description: Israel and Hezbollah were fighting at close range in southern Lebanon on Wednesday across steep, unforgiving terrain.

item.title: Zurich Stabbing: 3 Children Injured in Attack Near Daycare Center
item.description: The police in Switzerland’s largest city said they had arrested a 23-year-old man after a midday stabbing attack.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A man attacked several children in Zurich on Tuesday.
